message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The skin lesions and sexual history suggest a possibility of HPV infection. The fact that the lesions turn white after application of acetic acid solution confirms the diagnosis of HPV. Oral acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus, and topical mometasone is a steroid cream and not appropriate for viral infections. Parenteral benzathine penicillin is used to treat syphilis, which is not the most likely diagnosis in this case. Curettage, or removal of the lesions with a spoon-shaped instrument, is the most appropriate next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The photograph and symptoms suggest condyloma acuminatum, which is caused by human papillomavirus. Curettage, or removal of the lesions, is the most appropriate next step in management. Oral acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus, not human papillomavirus. Topical mometasone is a corticosteroid used to treat inflammation and would be useless in treating a viral infection. Parenteral benzathine penicillin is used to treat syphilis, which is not the cause of the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and appearance of the skin lesions, along with the fact that they turn white after application of dilute acetic acid, suggest condyloma acuminata or genital warts caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). Curettage or removal of the lesions is the most appropriate next step in management. Oral acyclovir is used to treat herpes, which is not the most likely diagnosis in this case, and topical mometasone is a corticosteroid that would not be effective against a viral infection like HPV. Parenteral benzathine penicillin is used to treat syphilis, which is also not the most likely diagnosis in this case.

The skin lesions, their appearance after acetic acid application, and the patient’s sexual history suggest that this is likely condyloma acuminatum caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). Curettage is an appropriate next step in management for this condition. While acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus, it is not indicated in this case. Mometasone is a topical steroid and is not indicated for this condition. Benzathine penicillin is used to treat syphilis, but there is no evidence of syphilis in this case.

Curettage is the most appropriate next step in management. Oral acyclovir is used to treat herpes. Topical mometasone is a steroid and is not appropriate for warts. Parenteral benzathine penicillin is used to treat syphilis, which is not consistent with the patient's presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of the lesions suggests they may be molluscum contagiosum, which is often sexually transmitted. The fact that they turn white after application of acetic acid solution confirms the diagnosis. Curettage is the most appropriate next step in management for molluscum contagiosum. Acyclovir can be used for herpes, but the lesions are not consistent with herpes. Topical mometasone can be used for certain skin conditions, but is not appropriate for molluscum contagiosum. Benzathine penicillin is used for syphilis, which is not suspected based on the presentation.

The lesions turn white after application of acetic acid, which is a characteristic finding. Oral acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus infections, not HPV. Topical mometasone is a steroid cream used to treat inflammation, which is not effective against HPV. Parenteral benzathine penicillin is used to treat syphilis, which would present with different symptoms. Curettage, or removal of the lesions, is the most appropriate next step in management.

Curettage is the most appropriate next step in management for this condition. Oral acyclovir is used for herpes simplex virus infection, topical mometasone is a steroid cream used for inflammatory skin conditions, and parenteral benzathine penicillin is used for syphilis.

Oral acyclovir is used to treat herpes simplex virus (HSV), which doesn’t seem to be the cause in this case. Mometasone is a corticosteroid and wouldn’t treat the underlying cause.
